title: Hi, I'm Veeedka, IT Projects and Operations Specialist for Riot Oceania. Ask me anything!
body:
Hey guys! 

I’m Victor Zanozin (Veeedka), Riot Oceania’s resident tech (or officially, IT Projects and Operations Specialist). I work on all the tech that supports Rioters every day and also on our esports broadcasts and events. I’m here for the next few hours to answer any questions you might have about me, what I do for Riot, and anything else you can think of! 

A brief history of me: I’ve been interested in computers and gaming since I was very young - I think my first computer was a broken Microbee (kinda showing my age a bit here). I grew up playing Day of the Tentacle, Relentless, Doom, Myst, Diablo, Starcraft and many others and over the years have never lost that love of gaming. I’ve worked in various IT roles in different parts of the country for nearly 15 years now and started with Riot Games late last year. 

Outside of work I still spend a lot of time gaming and exploring new tech, riding bicycles and motorbikes and travelling. 

Alright, I’m going to hand it over to you guys - Ask me anything!

EDIT: Okay guys, time for me to head home. Thanks for all of your questions, it's been fun answering them :)

Hey Veeedka, thanks for doing this!

Just curious about a couple of questions as someone studying to be a developer:
1. What is Riot's tech stack? (or just Riot OCE's, if it's different at all)
2. What would you look for in a potential candidate to become a Junior Developer at Riot?
3. Favourite Champ?

Adding onto Veeedka's answer for #1, here's some info they provide on the Riot Games Career website:

> We work with a diverse set of technologies, but most of all we value engineers who are eager to learn new ways to deliver value to players. Some examples of the technologies we currently use include (but are by no means limited to):

> * Node.js, Python, Java, Go, Ruby
* MongoDB, Riak, Redis, MySQL, ElasticSearch
* AWS, Linux, Nginx, Varnish
* Docker, Terraform, Ansible
* Graphite, Grafana, Sensu, New Relic

> We seek out engineers who have shipped products in multiple technology stacks, but we'd also consider experience in other technologies (for example .NET), if you can couple that with recent experience writing production code in some of the above-mentioned tech.

You can also give the careers website a perusal for similar positions you may be interested in, and their requirements/qualifications.

http://www.riotgames.com/careers/464476

Hey aba, you're welcome :) Thanks for the questions! 

1.) We use all sorts of different things for our internal infrastructure to our game servers to various other platforms we use for different systems. I can't really elaborate much more than this, unfortunately :( 
2.) Riot is all about attitude as well as aptitude. If you're a gamer at heart, love to help people and care about how you impact people and players it will really help. Technical skill will help too! 
3.) Veigar/Morgana. I'm trying to branch out though, I'm finding I'm pigeonholing myself a little.

From an outside perspective Riot Games seems VERY private and security conscience.

Of course without compromising things, how do you get your users to adhere to policies that seem stricter than the normal commercial world, in light of the fact the users are nearly ALWAYS a weak point in any IT security system?

What is the coolest piece of tech you get to play with every week?

It's always interesting to see how we're seen from a different point of view :) 

I agree with you - We are security conscious, as we have a lot of Rioters all around the world that we like to be able to make sure they feel safe and secure at work, and actually are so. We also have a lot of private IP that needs to be protected. 

I have worked for some major financial institutions all around the world, so I'm kind of used to the strict policies - When I got to Riot they were interested in making sure you knew why the policies they put in place were there (rather than a because-I-said-so type model) and were always happy to accept feedback on tightening or loosening certain policies or restrictions. 

I get to play with lots of stuff! Some things I can't really mention, but one thing is a viewing platform we use for pro players to watch games while they're not in the studios. We've been building extra functionality into that that I'm really proud of, makes our lives easier :)

Greetings Veeedka,

I have a few questions for you, 2 for fun and 2 a bit more serious:

* When you go about solving a problem tech wise, does it often create the idea of a new feature you could potentially add to what you are fixing? If so, are you able to share examples of this happening for you in the past?


*  Does OCE's smaller server population change the way you go about your role compared to if you were working on problems for the NA or EUW servers with much higher server populations?


* What race did you play in Starcraft?


* What team/state are you going for in the "League of Origin" event that Riot announced?

Thank you!

~Elam

Hey Elam! 

Sure, sounds good :) 

1.) It does quite often! A lot of the improvements I come up with are reactive from a problem we've had in the past. There's a few things we've done around collecting data from any minor issues on our stage PCs that have made our lives a bit easier. 

2.) It does - The environment here is quite different to NA/EU, and very different again to the environment in China/Korea. The different regions focus on different priorities that are more relevant to their local areas, but also being in this region lets us do a lot of things earlier than other regions and far more quickly. 

3.) Terran! Spamming siege tanks in siege mode was my winning strategy. It worked sometimes. 

4.) #IAMVIC! I've lived so many places I basically have my pick of supporting team, but who can beat that hashtag?

Thanks for the replies really cool to hear about all these inner workings of Riot from the tech side of things and the different roles of Rioters. As a side note I was a Zerg player myself when I used to play Starcraft back in the day, but originally was a Terran main as well.

If you don't mind me adding another question (Knew I was missing one) how did you come up with the name Veeedka?

Thanks again, and thanks for doing the AMA!

~Elam

Hey, no worries :) I loved the SC2 campaigns and played through WoL and HoTS completely. Didn't know there was even a Protoss game until the other day... Mind blown. 

Haha, sure! It was actually a mixture of a bunch of different things like my name, etc that someone came up with when I was in high school. It's kinda stuck due to it's uniqueness.
are the work computers the rioters use uniform or are they built differently for different uses?
The majority are uniform, but there are certain models of different PC/spec for different uses. Graphics editors/etc get different PCs to the normal spec, for example.

Hi there,

1. What specifically do you do in terms of tech? Is it computer networking, programming etc? You mentioned you were doing the esports part of the OPL, did you create the OPL website? If so, nice work - what is it built it in? Wapperlyzer tells me Angular 2 and Riotjs but easier to hear it from the horses mouth :D

2. How big is your tech team and what are the requirements for someone looking to join it in terms of technical aptitude and cultural fit?

3. If you do programming, do you prefer functional or class based programming? Do you have any particular languages/frameworks that you enjoy doing?

3. What's your favorite esports team (in Oceania, then internationally)?

Hey! 

1.) I support all of the Rioters PCs, office hardware, internal network, broadcast studio tech, the PCs our players play on in our studio, all of our esports shows tech, etc etc etc... There's a lot to do! I didn't make the OPL website though, but I agree - the guys who did make it are incredible wizards. 

2.) In OCE, it's basically just me! I have some assistance from colleagues with areas I'm not fully across, but I'm responsible for the lot here (in terms of the Rioters gear, the game servers and the like are looked after by separate teams). See my previous answer to aba above :) 

3.) In terms of programming, I really only dabble. I've been playing with Python and Ruby as of late. 

4.) Legacy locally, TSM/C9 for NA, and globally probably SKT T1!

do you play league much (given that it's kinda of your work, I could imagine reasons you might not but I'd be interested in whether you play and enjoy league outside of work) ?

and is it frustrating when the oce league community blames you guys for technical difficulties and ping and disconnects, when the real fault usually lies with their internet companies or with the local infrastructure rather than riot's servers?

As much as I can, yeah! I try to get as much play time in during the day as I can ("playtesting" and testing our equipment as part of my job is definitely a welcome benefit!) and it's fairly common when I get home as well. I love playing, but I'm not very good at it - Having people who are way better than me in the office and happy to help me learn to play better is definitely incentive to improve. 

It's not frustrating so much as we empathise with it - I used to work for an ISP, so I've seen the full range of problems from PC issues to telco pit/wiring issues to upstream carrier issues. We're affected by these things too so we totally understand the difficulties of playing with high ping or packet loss. If I know of a problem that we can fix or try to help get fixed, I do whatever I can to work on it - This is something that actually drew me to Riot in the first place, this "I-really-want-to-help" attitude and in particular an article on our Engineering blog (https://engineering.riotgames.com/news/fixing-internet-real-time-applications-part-ii).
